results.title: Pleuro
results.creator_credit: Jack Keane, Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture and Ted Davis
results.brief_description: Pleuropneumonia, the dread cattle disease. In one Victorian outbreak, 8000 cattle were quarantined and 7000 slaughtered. Despite a six month quarantine in NSW and a permit entry, northern cattle could introduce the disease again. The symptoms, hollow flanks, laboured breathing and dribble from the mouth, are not apparent in either the incubating or carrier animals. Farmers notify the local Department of Agriculture when the disease is first noticed. The suspect area is quarantined and all animals brought into the State in the same mob are blood tested in order to trace and eradicate the disease.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jack Keane, Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture and Ted Davis

results.title: Pleure Pas la Bouche Pleine = Don't Cry with Your Mouth Full
results.brief_description:
Annie and Frederic, aged 16 and 19 respectively, are courting during summer in Poitou. Secretly, Annie yearns for some more excitement and when Alexandre, superficially more sophisticated than the local boys, comes to Poitou, she gets it. Fragile and charming, this is a female rites of passage film, played in the context of happy family relationships and everyday people. Thomas brings to the whole enterprise an observant eye for the details of village life.

Credits: Director, Pascal Thomas ; writers, Pascal Thomas, Roland Duval, Suzanne Schiffman ; photography, Colin Mounier ; music, Vladimir Cosma.
Cast: Annie Cole, Frederic Duru, Jean Carmet, Christiane Chamaret, Bernard Menez, Daniel Ceccaldi.

results.title: Plenty of nothing
results.brief_description: This program looks at the growing number of farmers’ wives, in Canada, who are now seeking legal recognition for their role in the family farm business. Many of these women devote most of their time to the family business and also look after the household, and they now feel that they should be equal partners with their husbands in the business.

results.title: Pleasure faire
results.creator_credit: Peter Jones, ONF | NFB and Kris Paterson
results.brief_description: From British Columbia, a day at a youth festival reminiscent of the folk fairs of medieval times, organised by people who choose to live outside the usual social pattern. The Pleasure Faire offered crowds a wide variety of hand-made objects—jewellery, beadwork, leatherwork, art, pottery. More than that, it provided a day of music, minstrel songs, dancing, and people participating in the spirit of the occasion, free of any commercialism or constraint. A day of joy, relived through the film.

results.title: Pleasure Domes
results.creator_credit: Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School and Maggie Fooke
results.brief_description: Is Cannes really like St Kilda, or is it just a state of mind? Animated watercolour drawings and handcoloured photocopies of photographs shape this introspective reflection on the nature of landscape and the human response to it. Technically impressive, atmospherically scored and quite hypnotic in its effect, this is a very distinguished work.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School and Maggie Fooke

results.title: Please look after this bear
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The wonderful world of Paddington Bear”.
Presents an animated adaptation of Chapter I of the book “A Bear called Paddington” by Michael Bond. Narrated by Michael Hordern. Animation by Ivor Wood. Suitable for lower and middle primary levels.

results.title: Please don't pick the daisies
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Researchers”.
The Snowy Mountains of South East Australia, despite their rugged, unchanging appearance are, in reality, quite fragile and quite sensitive to the forces of nature and the presence of people. The wild beauty of Kosciusko’s alpine flora is recorded by a research team for a new book.
